text: Throughout Nebraska and the Midwest, our friends are dealing with the worst flooding in half a century. We must provide immediate help to those suffering. RT @RepCohen The housing crisis is serious in #Memphis. 1 in 4 renters pays 50% of their income or more in rent. That’s why I'm pleased to support the American Housing and Economic Mobility Act with @SenWarren and @RepRichmond. This bill will help to lower housing costs for renters & buyers. https://twitter.com/SenWarren/status/1105991414884769792 QT @SenWarren Whether you live in a city or a rural area – whether you’re part of the middle class or struggling to get there – the cost of housing is squeezing people all across this country. @RepRichmond & I have a plan to help fix America’s housing crisis. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D1lEhegXgAAJAkL.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1105989748718489600/vid/320x180/xrLGLx_0_3P_txiG.mp4?tag=11

I applaud this bipartisan effort to prevent never-ending wars. Our bipartisan initiative to halt the war in Yemen is one part of this critical effort to create a better foreign policy. https://twitter.com/votevets/status/1106925422472806401 QT @votevets Huge news! Conservative @ConcernedVets and progressive @VoteVets are on opposite sides of almost every policy issue, but today, we are announcing in the @nytimes that we are combining our power, to repeal the 2001 #AUMF and end #ForeverWars.
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/16/us/politics/vote-vets-concerned-veterans-america.html

Donald Trump wants to cut Social Security, but we have some bad news for him. We're not going to cut Social Security benefits. We're going to expand them.

If you want to know what subconscious bias looks like, it’s a headline saying “AOC is underwater with every group EXCEPT women, nonwhites, and 18-34 year olds.”

So older, conservative white men are considered “everyone” and everyone else is discounted as an exception.

Cool 👍🏽 https://twitter.com/numbersmuncher/status/1106562672491970562 QT @NumbersMuncher Gallup: As Americans become more familiar with AOC, the more unfavorably they view her. Her net favorable rating has dropped from -2 to -10, now at to 31-41 (was 24-26).

The real national emergency is the failed leadership of this President. 

Americans are dying in the streets from gun violence, too many are working more for less, and white supremacy is rising around the globe. 

We need a president who will speak truth and fight for the people.

RT @RepJoeKennedy Discriminatory housing policies that can be traced from slavery through segregation to our modern economy have built a wealth gap that devastates communities of color. @SenWarren’s American Housing & Mobility Act marks big step forward for all Americans. https://twitter.com/SenWarren/status/1105881053405814785 QT @SenWarren We're glad to have strong new partners in this fight to make housing more affordable for families & start to tackle the racial wealth gap caused by decades of housing discrimination. @RepRichmond, @RepPressley, @RepRashida & I know that change can’t wait. https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2019/03/13/warren-affordable-housing-bill-now-backed-ayanna-pressley-and-rashida-tlaib/CPUiBSNtrzjOwtE2XfaLPK/story.html

Let's be clear: We’re not going to solve our housing crisis by nibbling at the edges. We need to tackle it head on—with big, comprehensive solutions that match the size of the problems we have. That’s what my housing plan for America does.

Something that’s not talked about enough: the opportunity to have a job & earn a good paycheck remains out of reach for many Americans living with disabilities. That’s why I’ve just cosponsored a bill this week to strengthen employment opportunities for workers with disabilities.

Homeownership is out of reach for too many families—especially Black families. Decades of discrimination by the federal government denied families of color the same kinds of homeownership subsidies available to white families. We need to tackle this head on. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D1tAoLdX0AA4kmI.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1106547313680490498/vid/320x180/BB_ad52Hr35F-iY9.mp4?tag=11

If you're struggling to make ends meet—
Worrying about your kids having access to clean water and air—
If your health care bills are causing more pain than comfort—

you aren’t alone. We need to channel our common pain into a common purpose. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D10xrXHWwAAbpRH.jpg
The gap between white homeownership rates and Black homeownership rates is 30%—more than it was when housing discrimination was legal in 1960.

Government at all levels hasn’t done enough to tackle our housing problems. The federal government has reduced investments in housing for middle-class and lower-income families even as rents have gone up.

Americans owe over $1.5 trillion in student loan debt — surpassing credit card debt. We can’t ignore this crisis as it continues to hurt the livelihoods of student loan borrowers and harms our country. It’s vital we make college debt-free. Let’s end the crushing cycle of debt.

RT @SenMarkey Too many people struggle just to find a decent, affordable place to live. We have a housing crisis and we need bold solutions to match the scale of the problem. Proud to support @SenWarren’s new proposal that will build millions of new units and reduce rents. https://twitter.com/SenWarren/status/1105860636406362113 QT @SenWarren We need big, bold changes to solve our country’s housing crisis. @RepRichmond and I are reintroducing the American Housing & Economic Mobility Act to build 3.2 million new housing units, bring down rent by 10%, and take the first steps to address the racial wealth gap. http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1105860042912419842/img/Trnfyx-Tk7AapzWC.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1105860042912419842/vid/320x180/pQvtl_1L9PjWKGrI.mp4?tag=11

During the 2008 housing crisis, I traveled to NV to hear the stories of those who'd lost their homes. I was part of the panel that oversaw how the Treasury Department was spending the bank bailout money, and I wanted to make sure we heard from the people being hit the hardest.

In 1973, tennis player Billie Jean King beat Bobby Riggs in the highly anticipated “Battle of the Sexes” match, earning respect for women’s tennis. The U.S. Open started offering equal prize money to men and women thanks to her gender equality efforts. #WomensHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D10ONIMXgAM-l5w.jpg
